page.title: 09ECOLOGY
page.content: Most of the land in the 12 square kilometres at the mouth of the River Tees is reclaimed. The land on which Monsanto stands (North of the River Tees) was reclaimed since 1967. The reclamation of that land of the site of I.C.I. N. Tees and of the site of Shell Oil U.K. followed a similar method. Bunds were built to enclose lagoons, dumping of waste, especially slag, was used to fill these ponds and progresdively the water was pumpred out. Roads and rail tracks were embanked; indeed the roads occupied the positions of the original bunds. An area of over 12 square kilometres to the north of the river alone has been reclaimed in the last twenty years. The advantage of reclaimed land is that extensive flat areas are made available.
